slide.title: Why was the World Wide Web Invented?

ul.li: Tim Berners-Lee was a scientist at CERN particle accelerator lab in 1989.

Scientists were having problems sharing and collaborating on documents and research results, for example some of the word processing tools available in the late 1980's:
WordStar
WordPerfect
Microsoft Word
Apple Write
LaTex
Tim had an idea to not only share information between people, but with everyone.
Documents could reference each other through hyertext linking.

slide.title: Purpose of the World Wide Web

ul.li: Sharing information.
Common platform for viewing, creating, editing and linking online information.
Open standards for everyone to use and benefit from.

contents.p: Gives all users more options in using and interacting with web content. The following are a few examples:

ul.li:
Captions for videos are need by the people who are deaf, but are very useful for people who are:
Non-native speakers of the language being spoken on the video.
People with learning disabilities who may have auditory processing difficulties.
People in a noisy or quiet environment and cannot hear or listen to the audio.
Students learning new vocabulary in a course can see the spelling of the words to help them remember and understanding the new terms.
Users using key word searches on the caption text to find relavant portions of the video.

Keyboard interaction is required for people who cannot use the mouse, due to blindness or physical disability, but are also useful for:
Touch typists who prefer to use keyboard commands, rather than pointing with a mouse.
People who are traveling when using a mouse or track pad is difficult due to constraints on their seating positon and posture.
Access to information is a human right, not just a nice thing to do.
Accessible at the same time as everyone else gets the information.
Over 400 member organizations representing industry, governments and academic interests.

Develop open and royality free standards:
Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) Specifications
Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) Specifications
Portable Network Graphics (PNG) Specifications
Scallable Vector Graphics (SVG) Specifications
Mathematical Markup Language (MathML) Specifications
Interopability through at least 2 indepdent implementations
Automated testing of technologies using the speficications.
Write once and use on a wide variety of devices.
In the early days of the web the browser wars between Internet Explorer and Netscape Navigator highlighted the need for standards based web design.
No proprietary technologies or royalties for use.

contents.p: If it worked with some version of the JAWS screen reader and a particular version of Microsoft Internet Explorer, a website was consideed accessible.

slide.contents:
Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 2.1
Important Featuresh2>
International accessibility standard, including the United States Federal Section 508 requirements for web accessibility.
Technology agnostic, so understanding requires knowledge of features of specific technologies.
Requirements identify the goals for accessibility, not the techniques.
Techniques referenced by WCAG are not normative or comprehensive, but are deisgned to help people understand the requirement and feasibility of meeting the requirement.

Three levels of importance:
A: Highest priority (29)
AA: Next highest (21)
AAA: Lowest priority (28)
Meeting level A and AA requirements are used by most regulatory standards (e.g. Section 508) as the mimimum for conformance.
None of the WCAG techniques are considered normative, but some are idenitfied as sufficent and others advisory techniques.
